PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life in such a manner that it will be applicable to all persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply to a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A form of questionnaire to the person

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience and may be answered in any way you see fit. It is impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about answering all the questions. You may have sheets of paper if you want to give detailed answers or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you haven't already seen this and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below:

- All pioneer experiences

- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (By horseback at first, then visiting friends, etc.)

When we came to Hugh Bligh in 1880, the nearest Methodist church was at North Battleford, about 15 miles away. We had to make a long journey by horseback to attend services. The church was very small and the service was held in the schoolhouse. It was a difficult trip, but we enjoyed it.
So he went home. He had one boy and a girl with him, and he called them in and he killed the girl and thought that he had killed the boy. Then he cut his own throat with a mould knife. He threw the boy & girl into a bed, thought they were dead. A neighbor went over and saw how things went and came into H.O. and reported it. My dad drove the Methodist missionary out, and they found out what had happened. Rev. Harrison said the boy was still alive. He went to work and dressed the wound. Still alive, he went to work and dressed the wound. And they hailed west bound express and put him in hospital in Portage La Prairie and took him to hospital in Portage La Prairie and he came through all right. Some of the neighbors asked him what happened; he said the old fool just went crazy.
